p.content: Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase. Most languages have four sets of quantifiers:

li.content: , which modify the whole nominal phrase,
, which do not co-occur with any other modifers except adjectives,

p.content: Each type will be considered in turn.

section2.secTitle: Quantifiers which modify the whole nominal phrase

p.content: Quantifiers meaning
or
seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last) in a nominal phrase, in a position distinct from the other quantifiers but in the same place as degree words like
and
(which can also act as focus markers, to be dscussed in section
) and words that mean the same as
(which can also co-occur with
), so we will refer to them as special degree words. These words modify the whole nominal phrase, as in
and
. Note that
can occur in place of or before these other special degree words, as in
or
uses the following to express these notions:
In
, these are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase. The positive special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

p.content: The negative special degree elements are

case.caseText: phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase.
phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

, the positive special degree elements are not expressed as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase. Instead, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase as

phrasal clitics which attach either to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase or to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase.
prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.
either prefixes or suffixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase.

p.content: There is not any way to express 'not' modifying a nominal phrase in the language, however.

section2.secTitle: Quantifiers which do not co-occur with Determiners

p.content: The second set includes quantifiers like
, and
, which do not allow any other articles, demonstratives or possessors in the nominal phrase. English examples include
p.langData: almost every little girl that I see
p.content: and
. Because they take the place of articles, demonstratives and possessors, we will treat these quantifiers as determiners with their own phrase structure rule.

does not have a separate set of quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. Negation of a nominal phrase is expressed by the special degree elements only. The positive notions of
and
are either like
above or like the quantifiers which may co-occur with articles, demonstratives and/or possessors to be treated in the next section.

does not have a separate set of quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. Just as there is not any way to express the negative special degree element 'not', there is not any way to express 'no' modifying a nominal phrase in this language. The positive notions of
and
are either like
above or like the quantifiers which may co-occur with articles, demonstratives and/or possessors to be treated in the next section.
does not have a separate set of negative quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. Negation of a nominal phrase is expressed by the special degree elements only.
has the following positive quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase:
does not have a separate set of negative quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase, just as there was not any way to express the negative special degree element 'not'.
has the following positive quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase:
does not have a separate set of positive quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase. The positive notions of
and
are either like
above or like the quantifiers which may co-occur with articles, demonstratives and/or possessors to be treated in the next section.
has the following negative quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase:
has the following positive and negative quantifiers which act as the only determiner in the nominal phrase:
These quantifier determiners occur

after

p.content: the head noun.

text.content: All of the quantifier determiners can occur on either side of the noun.
There are restrictions as to which of these quantifier determiners can occur on each side of the noun.

examples of negative quantifier determiners in full nominal phrases include:
See section
for examples of the negative elements used in sentences and discussion of the negation constructions in
Other quantifiers, like
, and
, come in a different position in the nominal phrase. In English, this is after an article, demonstrative or possessor and before an adjective and noun, as in
. Further, these quantifiers can be modified by degree words such as
and
, as in
or
has the following quantifiers of this type:
does not have any degree words which modify the quantifiers.
has degree words which can modify the quantifiers. These degree words occur

case.caseText: before
after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the quantifier.

text.content: All of the degree words can occur on either side of the quantifier.
There are restrictions as to which of these degree words can occur on each side of the quantifier.

p.content: examples include:
Numbers cannot be modified by the degree words like the quantifiers can, though they occur in the same position. Cardinal numbers can, however, be modified by ordinal numbers and by
and
, as in
or
. Ordinal numbers and
and
can also modify nouns directly, as in
and
. Since these modifiers (including ordinal numbers) also act as regular adjectives in modifying nouns directly, they act syntactically like adjectives.
The basic forms for the cardinal numbers are given in the following chart:
Larger cardinal numbers can be compounds which may be written as separate words, such as
or
p.langData: six thousand one hundred and thirty three
p.content: . Examples of compound numbers in
include:
Based on the position of the unit number and any conjunctions, cardinal numbers in
are

case.caseText: left-
right-

p.content: headed.
In
, ordinal numbers

case.caseText: are formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number.
are all independent syntactic words, distinct from the cardinal numbers.
may be formed by adding an affix to the cardinal number, but some forms are independent syntactic words.

modify a cardinal number, as in
, they occur

after
on either side (but not both sides) of
on either side or on both sides of
before or on both sides of
after or on both sides of
on both sides of

p.content: the cardinal number.

text.content: All of the ordinal numbers can occur on either side of the cardinal number.
There are restrictions as to which of the ordinal numbers can occur on each side of the cardinal number.
